div.note: The old woman rushed to give orders, brandishing the authority of her master’s name, which always made everyone jump to attention, no matter who uttered it, for no one would be so bold as to use the name falsely.

She reached the Malanotte shortly before the carriage. As it approached, she descended from the sedan chair, waved to the coachman to stop, and went up to Nibbio, who had poked his head out the window, and whispered the master’s orders to him.
As the carriage came to a halt, Lucia woke with a start from the torpor into which she had fallen.
She felt her blood run cold, opened her eyes, and looked out the window.

Nibbio had stepped away. The old woman leaned her chin against the door, staring at Lucia, and said, “Come along, girl. Come, you poor child. Come with me, I’ve got orders to treat you well and to cheer you up.”
The sound of a woman’s voice gave the poor girl momentary comfort and courage, but she immediately sank into a darker fear.
“Who are you?” she asked in a trembling voice, staring at the old woman’s face with shock.
“Come, come, my poor child,” the woman kept repeating.
Inferring their master’s intentions from the old woman’s unusual kindness, Nibbio and the other two tried to cajole their captive into obeying.

But Lucia continued to survey her surroundings. Although the strange wild place and the close watch of her guards offered her no hope of rescue, she opened her mouth to scream. But before she could make a sound, Nibbio threatened her with the gag again, so she suppressed her cry, trembling. After a brief struggle, they grabbed her and forced her into the sedan chair.
The old woman climbed in after her. Nibbio told the other two henchmen to follow, and he quickly made his way up the hill to be at his master’s beck and call.
“Who are you?” Lucia fearfully asked the strange grotesque face before her. “Why have I been brought here? Where am I? Where are you taking me?”
“I’m bringing you to someone who wants to help you,” the old woman replied. “To a great man…those who he wants to help are the lucky ones!
Lucky you, lucky you.
Don’t be afraid, don’t be so sad; he ordered me to cheer you up.
You’ll tell him, won’t you? That I cheered you up?”
“Who is he? Why? What does he want from me?
I don’t belong to him.
Tell me where I am. Let me go! Tell them to let me go, to take me to a church. Please!
You’re a woman, too. In the name of the Blessed Virgin…!”

In her early years the old woman used to say that sweet and holy name devoutly, but she had not invoked it or even heard it uttered for so long. The words filled the wretch’s mind with a strange, slow confusion, like the memory of light in an old man blinded since childhood.

Meanwhile the Nameless One looked down from where he stood at the castle gates. He saw the sedan chair moving very slowly behind the carriage, and in front, at a distance that grew with each passing moment, Nibbio running uphill.
When Nibbio reached the top, his master beckoned to follow him into the castle.
“Well?” he said, coming to a stop inside a room.

“Couldn’t have gone better,” replied Nibbio with a bow, “the signal came on time, and so did the woman. There was no one around, and though she let out a single cry, no one appeared. The coachman was ready, the horses were in excellent shape, and there was no one on the road but…”
“But…?”
“But…to tell you the truth, I wish you had ordered me to shoot her in the back, so I wouldn’t have had to hear her talk or see her face.”
“What? What do you mean?”
“I mean that the whole time, the whole time…I pitied her.”
“Pity?
What do you mean you pitied her?
What do you know about pity?
What is pity, anyway?”
“I’d never felt it so clearly as I did this time. You see, pity is like fear: If it gets you in its grips, you lose your manhood.”
“Let’s hear what she did to make you pity her.”
“Oh, sir! It went on forever…her crying, pleading, the look in her eyes, turning as pale as a ghost. Then sobbing, and pleading again, with such words…”
“I don’t want her in my house,” the Nameless One thought as he listened to Nibbio. “I was a fool to agree to this. But I gave my word, I gave my word.

Once she’s far from here…” He looked up at Nibbio and commanded, “Enough of your pity. Mount your horse, bring along a partner, two if you like, and ride as fast as you can to the home of Don Rodrigo, you know who I mean.
Tell him to send…but right away, otherwise…”
Another even more imperious “No” from deep inside stopped him from finishing his sentence.
“No,” he said resolutely, as if issuing himself the order. “No, go and get some rest. And tomorrow morning…you’ll do what I tell you to do.”

“She’s got some devil on her side,” he thought once he was alone, his arms folded over his chest. He peered at an area on the floor where the moonlight had come in through a tall window, painting a square of pale light, crisscrossed by the thick grating and divided into even tinier pieces by the small window panes.
“Some devil or…some angel who’s protecting her.

To make Nibbio feel pity!…Tomorrow morning, tomorrow morning at the crack of dawn, I want her out of here, to meet her fate, and we’ll speak no more of her,” he went on to himself, as if he was speaking to a naughty boy whom he knew would not obey, “and we’ll think no more about her.
That idiot Don Rodrigo had better not drop by to pester me with his thank-yous, because…I don’t want to hear another word about her.
I did him a favor because…because I gave him my word. And I gave him my word because…I was destined to.
But I’ll make him pay well for this favor, I will.
Now let’s see…”

He wanted to list the most outrageous things he could demand as payment, almost as punishment, but once again he remembered those words: Nibbio felt pity! “How did she do it?” he continued, distracted by the thought.
“I want to see her…No, I don’t!…Yes, I do!”
Going from one room to the next, he found a staircase, groped his way in the dark, and went up to the old woman’s room and kicked at the door.
“Who’s there?”
“Open up!”
At the sound of his voice, the woman leapt to her feet. The bolt slid through its rings, and the door burst open.
From the threshold, the Nameless One cast a glance around and, by the light of a lamp burning on a side table, he could see Lucia huddled on the ground in the corner farthest from the door.
“Who told you to toss her there like a bundle of rags, you old hag?” he barked at the servant with an angry scowl.
“That’s where she wanted to sit,” the woman answered humbly, “I did everything I could to make her feel better. She can tell you herself; she refused to listen.”
“Get up,” the Nameless One said to Lucia as he approached her.

But the banging on the door, the squeak of its hinges, the appearance of that man, and the sound of his words had filled Lucia with fresh terror, and she shrank even deeper into the corner, burying her face in her hands, motionless except for the trembling of her body.
“Get up, I don’t want to hurt you. I might even help,” the Nameless One repeated.
“Get up!” that same voice intoned, indignant at having to give the same order twice.

As if jolted by her fear, the unhappy girl immediately got up on her knees, and joined her hands as if a sacred image was before her. She raised her eyes to the face of the Nameless One, then lowered them immediately, saying, “Here I am. Now you can kill me.”
“I told you I don’t want to hurt you,” replied the Nameless One in a softer voice, staring down at a face distraught with heartache and fear.
“Cheer up, cheer up,” said the old woman, “if he’s telling you he doesn’t want to hurt you…”
“So why,” Lucia continued, her voice shaking with fear but steady in the indignation that rises from despair, “why are you making me suffer the pains of hell?
What did I ever do to you?”
“Have you been mistreated?
Speak!”
“Mistreated?
They took me by trickery, by force! Why? Why did they take me? Why am I here? Where am I?
I’m a poor creature: What did I ever do to you?
In God’s name…”
“God, God,” the Nameless One broke in, “always on and on about God. Those who haven’t got the strength to defend themselves always have this God on their side. As if he’d spoken to them!
What do you expect from the word ‘God,’ anyway?
You think it’s going to make me…?” and he broke off his sentence.
“Oh, sir!
What do I expect? What can a poor girl like me expect? Only your mercy.
God will forgive many things for an act of mercy!
Let me go, for the love of God, let me go!
You, who will also have to face your maker one day: What do you have to gain from causing a poor creature so much suffering?
You have the power to give orders: So tell them to let me go!
They brought me here by force.
Send me with this woman to ***, where my mother lives.
Oh Blessed Virgin! My mother! My mother, for goodness’ sake, my mother!
Perhaps it is not far from here. I saw my mountains!
Why are you making me suffer?
Tell them to take me to a church.
I will pray for you for the rest of my life.
What would it cost you to say one word?
Ah, yes! I can see that you are moved to pity: Say the word, say it.
God will forgive many things for an act of mercy!”
“Why couldn’t she be the daughter of one of those dogs that banished me?” the Nameless One thought. “One of those cowards who wants me dead? Then I could enjoy her whining, and instead…”
“Don’t reject an inspiration to do good!” Lucia continued fervently, encouraged by the hesitation she could see in her tormentor’s face and demeanor.
“If you don’t do me this kindness, then God shall…He will let me die, and then my suffering will be over.
But what about you?
Maybe one day you, too…But no, no. I will always pray to God to deliver you from all evil.
What would it cost you to say one word?
If you were the one suffering this pain…”
“Come now, cheer up,” the Nameless One interrupted with a kind voice that astonished the old woman.
“Have I hurt you?
Have I threatened you?”
“No, you haven’t. I can see that you have a good heart, that you feel pity for me, this poor creature.
You could terrorize me more than anyone, you could kill me, if you wanted to, and instead you have…opened your heart a little.
God will reward you for this.
Carry out this act of mercy: Free me, free me.”
“Tomorrow morning…”
“No, free me now, immediately.”
“Tomorrow morning we will see, I’m telling you.
Come now, cheer up until then.
Get your rest.
You must be hungry. We’ll bring you something to eat now.”
“No, no, I’ll die if anyone comes in here: I’ll die.
Take me to church yourself. God will reward you if you do.”

“A woman will come by to bring you something to eat,” said the Nameless One. After those words, he, too, was dumbfounded that such a thought had crossed his mind, and that he had felt the need to comfort a little peasant girl.

“And you,” he continued immediately, turning to the old woman, “encourage her to eat. Make her sleep in this bed. And if she wants your company, fine. Otherwise, it won’t kill you to sleep on the floor for one night.
Cheer her up, I tell you. Keep her spirits up.
And I’d better not hear any complaints about you!”
At that, he moved quickly to the door.
Lucia leapt up and ran to hold him back and renew her pleas, but he was already gone.
“Woe is me!
Lock the door! Lock it right away!”
When she heard the door shut and bolted, she went back to huddling in her corner.
“Woe is me!” she exclaimed again, sobbing. “To whom can I turn now?
Where am I?
Tell me, tell me for goodness’ sake, who is that man, the one who spoke to me?”
“Who is he? Who is he?
You’d like me to tell you, would you?
You’ll just have to wait.
Now that he’s protecting you, you’ve let it go to your head. And you want an answer, do you, and you want to drag me into it?
Well, ask him yourself.

If I told you who he was, I wouldn’t hear the kind words you just heard from him, believe me. I’m too old for this,” she went on, muttering between her teeth, “damn the young girls, who always look so pretty, whether laughing or crying, and who always think they’re right.”
But at the sound of Lucia’s sobs, she remembered her master’s threatening words. She leaned over the poor huddled girl and added in a gentler voice, “Come now, I didn’t say anything bad. Cheer up.
Don’t ask me to tell you things I can’t discuss. Anyway, stop worrying.
If only you knew how many people wish he’d speak to them the way he spoke to you!
Cheer up now. Something to eat’ll be here in a second. And take it from someone who knows: Judging from his tone, it’ll be delicious.
And then you’ll go to bed, and…leave a little corner for me, too, I hope,” she added in a snippy voice, despite herself.
“I don’t want to eat, I don’t want to sleep.
Leave me alone; don’t come near. But don’t leave me!”

“No, no, don’t worry,” said the old woman as she walked away and sat on a rickety chair, glowering at the poor girl with both fear and resentment. Every now and then, she gazed longingly at the comfortable nest she had made, aggravated that she might not be able to settle into it all night, and grumbled about the cold.
But she cheered up at the thought of supper and the hope that there would be enough for her, too.
Lucia, as if in a trance or a feverish dream, didn’t notice the cold, didn’t feel hungry, and only vaguely sensed her own suffering and fear.
When someone knocked, she gave a start and raised her terrified face, crying, “Who’s there? Who’s there?
Don’t let anyone in!”
“It’s no one, no one,” said the old woman. “Good news. It’s just Marta bringing a bite to eat.”
“Lock the door, lock the door!” cried Lucia.
“Right away, right away!” replied the old woman. Taking a basket from Marta’s hands, she sent her away, closed the door, and placed the basket on a table in the middle of the room.

She begged Lucia repeatedly to come and enjoy the good food, trying to find the right words to get the poor girl to eat, bursting into exclamations of how exquisite the meal was: “Folks like us never get to taste this type of food! We’ll remember this for a very long time!
This is the wine that the master drinks with his friends when one of them comes by and they want to have a good time!
Mmm!”
But all her coaxing was in vain. “Since you don’t want anything,” she grumbled, “don’t go telling the master tomorrow that I didn’t cheer you up.
I’m going to have a bite to eat myself, but there’ll be more than enough left over for you when you get your head back on straight and are ready to obey.”
At this, she started to eat greedily.
Once she’d had her fill, she stood up, went to the corner, and hovering over Lucia, invited her once again to eat and then go to bed.
“No, I don’t want anything,” the girl replied in a faint, drowsy voice.
Then, more resolutely, she asked: “Is the door bolted? Bolted securely?”
After looking around the room, she stood up, and groping with her hands, walked suspiciously toward the door.
The old woman ran ahead of her, placed her hand over the bolt, and shook it, saying, “Can you hear it? Can you see? Is that secure enough for you?
Now are you happy?” “Me? Happy? Here?” answered Lucia, returning to her corner.
“At least God knows where I am!”
“Get in the bed. What are you doing over there in the corner, curled up like a dog?
Who ever heard of refusing a little comfort when it’s there for the taking?”
“No, no, let me be.”
“Suit yourself.
Look, I’m leaving you a good spot. I’ll sleep on the side. I’ll be uncomfortable for your sake.
If you want to get into the bed, you know how…Remember, I’ve asked you several times.”
With that she slipped under the covers, fully dressed, and silence descended over the room.
Lucia remained motionless in the corner, rolled up into a ball, her face buried in her hands.
She was neither asleep nor awake, for her mind was racing through a murky sequence of thoughts, images, and fears.

One second she was alert, remembering the horrors she had seen and suffered that day, agonizing over the mysterious and terrifying reality that had engulfed her. The next, her thoughts wandered to an even darker place, struggling with phantoms born of fear and uncertainty.
Finally, she stretched her tortured limbs and lay down or rather collapsed into a sleeplike state, more exhausted and depressed than ever.
But suddenly, as if an inner voice jolted her awake, she woke, gripped by an unconscious need to be fully alert, think clearly, and find out the where, how, and why of her situation.

A noise made her prick up her ears: It was the slow rattle of the old woman snoring. Lucia opened her eyes and saw a faint light appearing and disappearing. It was the wick of the dying lamp that sputtered out a flickering light and immediately withdrew it, like the ebb and flow of the waves upon the shore. The light illuminated then fled from the objects in the room before she could make out their distinct shapes and colors, offering nothing more than a series of jumbled images to her gaze.
But very quickly, she recalled the trappings of the room; her confused senses righted themselves, and the unhappy girl recognized her prison.

The memories of the horrible day and her dread of the future came flooding back. New fears replaced any sense of calm she had felt after so much agitation, her brief repose, and her state of abandonment, and she was so overcome with distress that she wanted to die.
But in that moment, she remembered that at least she could pray, and suddenly hope leapt into her heart.
She picked up her rosary once again and started to say her Hail Marys. As she recited the prayers through trembling lips, her heart was filled with a vague sense of trust.
Suddenly, another thought crossed her mind: Perhaps if she offered a sacrifice in this moment of desolation, an answer to her prayers might be more likely.
In this moment, filled with fear and a desire for freedom, she remembered the one thing that was most important to her in the world, and she immediately resolved to make that offering.
She rose to her knees, clasped her hands to her breast, her rosary beads dangling from her fingers, lifted her face toward heaven, and said, “Oh Blessed Virgin!
You to whom I have prayed so many times, and who so many times has consoled me!

You who have suffered so much pain and are now in glory, and have performed so many miracles for poor troubled souls, help me! Help me to escape from this danger and lead me back to safety with my mother, oh Mother of God, and I vow to you to remain a virgin for the rest of my life, and to renounce my poor love forever, and belong to no one but you.”

After uttering these words, she lowered her head and placed the rosary beads around her neck, a sign of consecration, as well as protection, as if she were suiting up in the armor of a new militia into which she had enlisted.
Sitting back down on the floor, a sense of tranquility and confidence filled her spirit.
She remembered the powerful stranger’s words about “tomorrow morning,” and in them, found a promise of salvation.
As daybreak approached, Lucia fell into a deep uninterrupted sleep, exhausted by her struggle and comforted by new hope with the name of her protectoress still on her lips.
At the same time, someone else in the castle yearned for sleep, but could find no peace.

After he had left or rather fled from Lucia, ordered her supper, and made his usual rounds of the castle, the Nameless One—with her vivid image in his mind’s eye and her words echoing in his ears—had retreated to his room, quickly locking himself in as if to barricade himself from a squadron of enemies. After undressing just as quickly, he went to bed.
But that image, more present than ever, mocked him, as if to say, “No sleep for you tonight.”
“Why did you want to see her?” he wondered. “Out of some stupid girlish curiosity?
That idiot Nibbio is right: She takes away your manhood…And me?…Am I no longer a man?
Me?
What happened? What the devil got into me? What’s different this time?
Didn’t I already know how women behave?
Sometimes men act this way, too, when they can’t fight back.
What the devil! You’d think I never heard a woman whining!” —
And here, without having to dig too deep, his memory retrieved more than one instance when neither prayers nor laments had deterred him from carrying out his intentions.

But rather than restoring his determination to execute the task at hand, or extinguishing the pity gnawing at his soul, these memories stirred up a kind of terror, an indistinct rage of repentance in him.
So he was relieved to return to that first image of Lucia, which he hoped would restore his courage.
“She’s alive,” he thought, “she’s here. It’s not too late. I can tell her, ‘Go, be happy again,’ I can see her expression change. I can even say, ‘Forgive me.’…Forgive me?
Me, ask for forgiveness? From a woman? Me!
And yet…If a word, a single word, could benefit me, free me from this devilry, then I’d say it! Yes, I would!
What is happening to me?
I’m not a man anymore!

“Enough!” he said, turning angrily in his bed, which had become hard as a rock, with covers that had become as heavy as lead. “Enough! This isn’t the first time such nonsense has passed through my mind.
This, too, will pass.”
And to make it pass, he tried to think of something important, something that used to keep him occupied, so he could concentrate on that alone, but he found nothing.

Everything seemed to have changed: The things that he used to desire the most were no longer desirable in the least; his passion, like a horse that suddenly balks at shadows, refused to take another step.

At the thought of business he had begun, but not yet finished, he did not feel driven to complete it, or was irritated by the obstacles standing in the way (it would have been a relief to be irate in that moment!). Instead, he felt sad, almost horrified, at the steps he had already taken.

Time appeared before him stripped of all intention, all activity, all desire, filled only with appalling memories. All those hours became one with the hour that was now passing so slowly and weighing on him so heavily.

He imagined all his henchmen lining up before him, but he couldn’t think of a single order to give them that mattered. Indeed, the very idea of seeing them again, of finding himself among them, was a new burden, an idea both repugnant and annoying. The only thought that came to him for the next day was to free that poor girl.
“I’ll free her, yes, as soon as day breaks, I’ll run to her and say, ‘Go now, go.’
One of my men will accompany you…What about my commitment?
My word of honor? And Don Rodrigo?…Well, who the hell is Don Rodrigo, anyway?”

Like a man caught off guard by an embarrassing, unexpected question from his superior, the Nameless One tried to think of an answer to the question that he, or rather his new self, had posed, rising up all at once, terrifyingly, in judgment of his old self.

He tried to understand what had driven him, almost before being asked, to agree to inflict suffering on this unhappy stranger—a girl he neither hated nor feared—as a favor to Don Rodrigo. Though there were plenty of excuses he could have invented up, he still could not explain to himself what had brought him to that point.

His willingness had stemmed not from a deliberation but from an instinct, in obedience to his old habits and the consequence of a thousand previous actions. But as he sought a reasonable explanation for even a single deed, the tormented self-examiner found himself engulfed in an interrogation of his whole life.

Back and back he went in time, from year to year, commitment to commitment, bloodshed to bloodshed, crime to crime. In his newly awakened conscience, each crime reappeared stripped of the feelings that had made him want to commit it, and with a monstrosity that those feelings had kept him from seeing.
They all belonged to him; they were who he was. The horror of this realization was reborn with each image and joined to all of them, driving him to despair.

He sat up in a fury, and reached in a fury toward the wall next to the bed for his pistol and took hold of it, ready to end his unbearable life, in the grips of terror and a lingering apprehension. But then he thought of the future, the days after his death that would continue to flow.

With horror, he imagined his mutilated corpse, lying motionless, left to the mercy of the lowliest survivor. The shock and confusion that would spread throughout the castle the next day, everything upside down, as he remained powerless, speechless, his body tossed who knows where.
He imagined the gossip, from near and far, the jubilation of his enemies.

The darkness and silence of the night made death seem even more grim and frightening. If he were to have these thoughts in broad daylight before a crowd, he might not hesitate to jump in a river and disappear.

Lost in these tormented contemplations, his twitching thumbs fiddled with his pistol as another thought crossed his mind. “What if the afterlife, the one they assured me was certain when I was a boy, doesn’t exist? What if it’s an invention of the priests? What should I do then? Why should I die? What does it matter what I’ve done?
What does it matter? I must be crazy to be thinking this…but what if, instead, this other life exists?”
This doubt, this possibility, sank him into an even deeper, heavier despair from which there was no escape, not even through death.
He dropped the weapon and sat there with his hands in his hair, teeth chattering, his whole body trembling.
Suddenly he remembered the words he had heard a few hours earlier: “God will forgive many things for an act of mercy!”
Though previously spoken in a humble, prayerful tone, they came to him now ringing with authority and a distant hope.

In that moment, he felt relief coursing through his veins. As he regained his composure, he removed his hands from his temples and thought about the person who had said these words. She was no longer his prisoner, or a supplicant, but his guide, dispensing grace and consolation.

He anxiously awaited daybreak, so he could run to free her and hear her speak more words of refreshment and life. He imagined escorting her to her mother. “And then? What will I do tomorrow for the rest of the day? What will I do the day after tomorrow?
And during the night, which will return again in twelve hours?
Oh, the night! No, no, the night!”
Once again falling back into the painful contemplation of an empty future, he wondered in vain how he would use his time, and how he would get through the days and nights.

At first, he imagined abandoning the castle and moving to a distant land where no one knew either him or his name, though he realized his old self would always haunt him. But then a dim hope revived that this was just a temporary delirium, and his old spirit and desires would return. One moment, he dreaded the day, for his people would see how low he had fallen. In the next, he longed for it, in the hope that it would also shed light on his tumultuous thoughts.
At the break of dawn, shortly after Lucia had fallen asleep, while the Nameless One sat motionless, he heard a wave of sound, indistinct but vaguely joyous.

Listening carefully, he was able to make out the distant ringing of bells of celebration. A few moments later, he heard the bells echo off the mountain, languidly repeating the tune and harmonizing with it.
The festive ringing seemed to be coming closer and closer.
“What cause is there for celebration? What do they all have to be so cheerful about?” He leapt out of his bed of thorns and, half-dressed, ran to open a window and look out.

The mountains were partly veiled in fog. The sky was overcast beneath a single ashen cloud. As daylight slowly spread, however, he spotted people walking on a road at the other end of the valley, joined by others coming out of their houses, all heading in the same direction, toward the pass on the right of the castle, dressed in their Sunday best and moving with remarkable enthusiasm.

“What the devil are they up to? What is there to be happy about in this damned town? Where is all this rabble going?” Calling to a trusted bravo sleeping in the next room, he asked what the reason was for all the hubbub.
But the man knew as little as he did, and replied that he would go down immediately to find out.
The Nameless One continued to lean out the window, riveted by the spectacle moving through the valley.

There were men, women, children; some traveling in groups, others in pairs, while some were alone. One man rushed to catch up to the person in front of him, and the two walked together. Another left his house and paired up with the first person he saw, as if they were two friends setting off on a trip they had planned.

Everyone he saw seemed to be united by a common haste and joy. The jarring but harmonious ringing from the various bell towers—some closer, some farther—seemed to articulate the voice underlying those gestures, and provide the words he could not hear from his perch.
Filled with something greater than curiosity, he sought to discover what could give such an equal passion to so many different people.
